title: Had Anne Boleyn given King Henry VIII a son, would he have done away with Jane Seymour? - Quora

response.answer_text: If Anne had been successful in producing a male heir, she would have been on Easy Street for the rest of Henry’s life - which was only another 11 years — and probably the child’s Regent until he became of age to rule after Henry died. Jane Seymour may have been one of Henry’s playthings, but very probably not a wife. Unfortunately, the shock of his serious jousting accident (even after she asked him not to participate) led her to a miscarriage on Jan 29, 1536 (ironically, the same day as Queen Catherine’s funeral). Less than four months later, she was executed. The serious jousting accident (leg injury and probable concussion) is theorized to have led to personality changes in Henry, either through traumatic brain injury (affecting his impulsivity and reasoning) or the sheer weight of the uncurable pain in his legs (the smell of the infection was said to be discernable from the next room, by some courtiers.) Anne knew Jane Seymour — she and Jane had been maids of honor for both the Princess Mary (Henry’s sister) during her brief marriage to Louis XII of France (corrected), and then again as maids of honor to Queen Claude, the wife of Louis’ successor. It’s probably one reason why Jane and her sister, Elizabeth, were accepted as a maids of honor for Anne’s court when she married the king in 1532 (secretly)/1533 (publicly) and birthed the future Elizabeth I 8–9 months later. After that, she had probably three miscarriages. She had begun to see signs of Henry favoring Jane (he had gifted her with a locket wth his picture in it), and Anne had discovered Jane perched on Henry’s knee and flew into a rage. None of that would have probably happened if she had had a boy — she would have been secure enough to remove Jane from court, or probably to just overlook it until the King’s passion had burned out. After her third miscarriage, most people felt that she had “miscarried of her Savior”, the only thing that would have held her marriage together. Cromwell was happy to make Anne the scapegoat for Henry’s interest in Jane — and the rest is history. Cromwell’s son, Gregory, went on to marry Jane’s sister, Elizabeth, in August 1537 after Elizabeth asked Thomas Cromwell for help after her first husband died. Cromwell saw an advantage to marrying his son to the King’s sister-in-law, but alas, her sister, Jane, died a few weeks later, and Cromwell himself was executed in 1540 after Henry’s disasterous marriage to Anne of Cleves, which he had helped engineer.

If Elizabeth Tudor had been a boy, Jane Seymour probably wouldn’t have even bothered to try to woo the King because there is no way he’d even think of ditching Anne. That’s not to say he wouldn’t have continued sleeping around but he most assuredly would not have been looking for another wife, definitely not. While he’d pursued her, he’d built up in his mind that she was the perfect, son producing woman for him and if she’d been lucky enough to have a boy first go, he would have been crowing to the rooftops about how he’d been so right all along to ditch his first wife for her. Anne never had a choice in this matter, she resisted but eventually saw it as God’s plan for her. She’d have still had enemies but her detractors would have had far less of a leg to stand on if she’d given him a boy straight away. Jane had a go at the king after he’d had a daughter and was very displeased with his wife. She did this with the help of Katherine of Aragon’s and Mary Tudor’s supporters, seizing her opportunity and presenting herself as the perfect woman with their teachings. This would have been utterly fruitless if a son had been had, first go. Anne would never complain about the mistresses, she’d simply do her duty as queen and look out for her son. Henry would very much respect her and she’d be safe. If she’d still had Elizabeth and Jane Seymour had started her overtures, but Anne went on to have a live son, then Henry would have been appeased. Two healthy children, one a son, would have soothed his ego nicely and he’d console himself that he was indeed right to go with Anne. So he’d be no longer interested in a possible replacement and Jane would probably have to retreat. Being a king’s mistress would bring her nothing and she might end up ‘ruined’ and unable to marry. She might not even appeal to Henry as a mistress as she’d presented herself as the perfect docile, obedient wife. But safe to say, if Anne had given Henry a live, healthy boy, he would not have gotten rid of her.
